normalised: New Delhi Faces Deteriorating Air Quality Ahead of Festive Season

unnormalised: New Delhi – Air quality in the National Capital Territory is showing a concerning decline ahead of the Diwali festival, prompting renewed scrutiny of pollution control measures. The Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) recorded an Air Quality Index (AQI) of 285 at Anand Vihar this morning, classified as ‘poor’.
normalised: New Delhi – Air quality in the National Capital Territory is showing a concerning decline ahead of the Diwali festival, prompting renewed scrutiny of pollution control measures. The Central Pollution Control Board (C P C B) recorded an Air Quality Index (A Q I) of two hundred and eighty five at Anand Vihar this morning, classified as ‘poor’.

unnormalised: Experts attribute the worsening air to a combination of vehicular emissions, industrial activity, and seasonal factors, including the burning of crop residue in neighboring states like Haryana and Punjab. Dr. Sharma from TERI emphasized the need for stricter enforcement of existing regulations.

unnormalised: The Delhi government has announced a graded response action plan (GRAP) to combat the deteriorating conditions, including intensified water sprinkling and restrictions on construction activities. This year's Diwali celebrations might also face restrictions on firecracker usage, with the aim of minimizing the adverse impact on air quality.

unnormalised: Residents are advised to take necessary precautions, especially those with respiratory ailments. Many are opting for air purifiers and N95 masks. Health advisories warn against prolonged outdoor activities. The situation remains under close observation, hoping for improvement before the festive season fully commences. The aroma of biryani, usually a Diwali staple in many homes, is often overpowered by the smog at this time.
